Elaboration: Grouping short sentences about the same topic to produce an original text, for example ‘Frogs are green. Frogs have big eyes. They eat insects.’, or writing a series of short statements in time sequence, for example ‘I eat breakfast. I go to school. I read a book.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write sustained texts using sentences based on simple, repetitive, modelled patterns
Elaboration: Using basic conjunctions and connectives to show time and sequence, for example in ‘On Saturday I … We went … We saw … I went … Then I … And then …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write sustained texts using sentences based on simple, repetitive, modelled patterns
Elaboration: Connecting clauses to make compound sentences that may run on, for example in ‘I came to school and met my friend and then we played handball and then the bell went.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write sustained texts using sentences based on simple, repetitive, modelled patterns
Elaboration: Using ‘because’ to create dependent clauses, although these may be incomplete sentences, for example in ‘We went to the pool. Because it was hot.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write sustained texts using sentences based on simple, repetitive, modelled patterns
Elaboration: Connecting clauses into basic compound or complex sentences using common conjunctions such as ‘and’, ‘but’, ‘and then’, ‘because’ and ‘so’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write sustained texts using sentences based on simple, repetitive, modelled patterns
Elaboration: Using simple pronoun references to avoid repeating the subject in consecutive sentences, for example in ‘Ahmed came to school early. He felt very tired.’ and ‘Yesterday the class went … We went …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Using common, simple past tense forms with the suffix ‘-ed’ consistently, although overgeneralising rules for some less common irregular past tense verbs (such as in ‘catched’, ‘freezed’ and ‘waked’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Using common irregular past tense verbs accurately, for example ‘went’, ‘said’ and ‘had’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Using more complex tenses inconsistently, for example in ‘I have never eat it before.’ and ‘We caught the train then walk to the park.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Using some common imperatives appropriately, for example ‘Draw …’, ‘Stop.’, ‘Mix the …’ and ‘Cook the …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of basic verb forms accurately
Elaboration: Expressing simple negative constructions accurately, for example ‘I do not like …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language

Subject: English as an Additional Language

Elaboration: Using simple comparative adjectives in basic sentences with varying accuracy, for example in ‘My brother is bigger than me.’

Elaboration: Using learnt topic-specific vocabulary in simple modelled sentences

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use high-frequency words encountered in classroom activities

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use high-frequency words encountered in classroom activities

Subject: English as an Additional Language

Subject: English as an Additional Language
